author: VNExplorer
title: Why Hemant Soren made a swift comeback as Jharkhand CM
text: In Jharkhand's turbulent political landscape, Hemant Soren has made a swift rebound to reassert his pivotal position. After securing bail on June 28 in an alleged money-laundering case, Soren wasted no time in resuming his role as chief minister of the state. Soren was reinstated to the post on July 4, with governor C.P. Radhakrishnan administering the oath of office. Champai Soren, who had stepped in as stopgap chief minister following Hemant's arrest by the Enforcement Directorate (ED) on January 31, gracefully made way. He has been appointed a cabinet minister in the new Jharkhand Mukti Morcha (JMM)-led coalition government, which has Congress and the Rashtriya Janata Dal (RJD) as partners. The new Hemant administration strengthened its position on July 8 by winning the trust vote in the legislative assembly, securing 45 votes in the 81-member House. This marks the ruling coalition's third government in the current term of the assembly, following their significant victory over the BJP in the November 2019 state election. The second government was formed in February this year when Champai, a senior JMM leader, assumed the role of chief minister after Hemant's resignation and subsequent arrest. Hemant is back at the helm just as the state begins to pace up for the assembly elections, due in October-November, amidst a dynamic political climate. Many had expected Hemant to allow Champai to continue with the top job till the elections. However, Hemant's return is a strategic move by the JMM to put its best foot forward in the run-up to the polls. Champai, despite his efforts, lacked the charisma and assertion needed to galvanise support or inspire confidence among party supporters. He was also perceived as somewhat lacking in stature and adequate popularity. Hemant's return, then, offers the coalition the opportunity to mobilise its vote bases for the forthcoming electoral battle against the BJP. Hemant's quick return to the political fray also underscores a heightened sense of urgency. The JMM-Congress-RJD alliance faces significant challenges in the upcoming election despite securing all five Scheduled Tribe-reserved seats in the Lok Sabha polls. The BJP-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA) clinching the remaining nine parliamentary seats highlights its enduring influence and support base in the state. For the ruling coalition, the positive takeaways from Hemant's return are profound: the triumph in tribal strongholds in the Lok Sabha polls not only underscores its dominance among the tribal community but also strategically positions it for the assembly polls. The 28 of Jharkhand's 81 assembly seats reserved for Scheduled Tribesâover a third of the totalâcan be a key determinant in returning to power. Hemant has already shifted into campaign mode to seize the momentum. Meanwhile, the BJP, reeling from losses in the Scheduled Tribe-reserved Lok Sabha seats, has strategically appointed party stalwart Shivraj Singh Chouhan and Assam chief minister Himanta Biswa Sarma as election in-charges for Jharkhand. Sarma's engagements with key tribal leaders, including former Union minister Arjun Munda; Sita Soren, MLA and estranged daughter-in-law of JMM chief Shibu Soren; and Geeta Koda on June 29 reflect a concerted effort to bolster appeal among tribal voters. In a state where Scheduled Tribes comprise over 26 per cent of the electorate, their sway cannot be underestimated. The defeat of Munda in the Lok Sabha polls might indirectly benefit the BJP as he can focus on reviving the party's waning tribal support in Jharkhand. However, the move also risks internal discord, given Munda's complex equation with BJP state president Babulal Marandi. Hemant's bail and return as chief minister just ahead of elections may take some sting out of the BJP's narrative of corruption and lawlessness against the JMM. It may also prompt tribal voters to question the validity of the charges against their chief minister and the integrity of the investigation led by a central agency. The BJP will need to recalibrate its campaign strategy in light of these developments. Hemant's arrest proved to be a blessing in disguise for his party. During his absence, wife Kalpana Soren emerged as a prominent political figure. Recognised for her eloquence and ability to connect with voters, Kalpana is seen has having significantly bolstered the JMM's support base, particularly among women and the tribal community. Her active role in the Lok Sabha poll campaign and her decisive victory in the Gandey by-election by a substantial margin of 26,000 votes underscore her burgeoning influence. Hemant's return as chief minister sets the stage for an electrifying assembly election campaign and an altered political dynamic in Jharkhand. As both coalitions gear up to slug it out, it will be the electorate's response to unfolding developments that will determine the outcome of what promises to be a crucial and perhaps game-changing election.
